choices.text: The cochlear implant electrode stimulates the cochlear nerve endings
The multicannel implant gives better outcome for the patient
8th nerve integrity is essential  for the cochlear implant successful outcome.
The implant electrode is placed through Oval window .

questions.text: All of the following are true about cochlear implant surgery except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The implant electrode is placed through Oval window .

  1. Cochlear Implant is a device that converts sound to electrical energy and  directly stimulates cochlear nerve fibres electrically

 

Parts of cochlear implant:

A.External parts

Microphone

Speech processor

Transmitter

 

B. Internal parts

Reciever stimulator + electrode 

 

Surgical technique..

A.   The classical approach is  posterior tympanotomy (facial recess approach)

B. Other surgical technique is Veria approach….  This is transcanal approach

 

Insertion of electrode through Cochleostomy/or through round window membrane

Types:

Single channel (house- 3M device)

Multiple channel  ( nucleus device)- 22 channel—much better

 

Ideal cases of cochlear implant are post lingual deaf ( the one who turns deaf after developing normal speech)

 

Where the electrodes are placed? 

Scala tympani

                   

Patient selection

 

Bilateral profound or severe to profound hearing loss with no benefit seen with hearing aid

 

Grading of hearing loss

Mild                               26-40db

Moderate-                             41-55 db

Moderately severe                56-70 db

Severe                           71-90 db

Profound                      more than 90 db

 

Speech therapy is  must after cochlear implantation

 

Mondini dysplasia of cochlea refers to the condition when there are one and half turns of cochlea rather than two and half. There is absence of the apical modiolus and interscalar septum, resulting in an incomplete partitioning of the cochlea together with an enlarged vestibular aqueduct (EVA) and dilated vestibule.This is not a contraindication of cochlear implantation

choices.text: It has surgically implantable titanium fixture
it transmits sound directly to cochlea through the bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration
It is indicated in patients with External Auditory canal atresia
It is not indicated in patients with chronic discharging ear with hearing loss

questions.text: All of the following are true about bone anchored hearing aid except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)  

It is not indicated in patients with chronic discharging ear with hearing loss

BAHA- bone anchored hearing aid will be given to hearing impaired individuals where conventional hearing aids can not be given like in bilateral Anotia, EAC atresia, discharging ear, EAC stenosis. Its  a specialised device which is surgically fitted partly on to mastoid bone. it transmits sound directly to cochlea through the bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration

questions.text:
A congenitally profoundly deaf child on radiological evaluation of cochlea and brain with MRI/CT scan has been found to having Mondini’s Dysplasia of cochlea with presence  of normal  eighth nerve on both sides.  He has shown no benefit with 6 months of hearing aid use.

What is the best method of hearing rehabilitation in this case
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cochlear implant surgery

  1. Brain stem implant is placed on lateral recess of 4th ventricle near cochlear nucleus for stimulation.

The indications are- NF-2 cases with bilateral acoustic neuromas, congenital absence of VIII nerve, cochlear aplasia(Michel’s)

choices.text: Korner septum is remnant of petrosquamous suture
Subiculum is a bony spicule which separates oval and round windows
Processus Cochleariformis indicates the basal turn of cochlea.
Pyramid  lies on the posterior wall of middle ear

questions.text: Not a true match about the anatomical aspects of ear
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Processus Cochleariformis indicates the basal turn of cochlea.

Trautmann’s triangle---This is a triangular space bounded by –

  • Bony labyrinth anteriorly
  • Sigmoid sinus posteriorly
  • Dura containing superior petrosal sinus superiorly.

Boundaries of Macewen's triangle are as follows:

  • Superiorly: Suprameatal crest
  • Anterior-inferiorly: Posterosuperior wall of external auditory canal
  • Posteriorly: A tangential line to posterior canal wall

 

 

 

Facial recess boundaries

  • Medial boundary—vertical segment of facial nerve
  • Lateral boundary—chorda tymapani
  • Superior boundary—fossa incudis ( short process of incus)

questions.text: One of the following is a feature of meniere’s disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diplacusis 

Meniere’s disease

Aetiology: defective absorbtion of endolymph

Age: 35- 60 years, M>F, usually unilateral disease

Tinnitus may persist in between attacks

Patient cannot tolerate loud sounds due to recruitment

Fluctuating hearing loss

Diplacusis-patient can hear same sound in 2 frequencies

Tullio's phenomenon may be positive (vertigo on hearing loud sounds)

Recruitment is present

Electocochleography--- increased SP/AP ratio> 30%

PTA shows low frequency SNHL in early stages (Rising audiogram)

SISI score – short increment sensitivity index score of a cochlear disease patient is even better than normal ( more than 70 %)

Primary treatment of meniere’s disease is medical management. Refractory patients  are offered further treatments. like transtympanic injection of gentamicin using microwicks or microcatheters. Meniete device is external device used for pulse pressure therapy to labyrinth.  Donaldson’s  line is surgical landmark for localisation of endolymphatic sac to conduct endolymphatic sac decompression therapy

questions.text: Name the audiological investigation In which this type of ear probe is used
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Otoacoustic emissions

OAE are the cochlear echoes produced by outer hair cells of cochlea.

 

BERA is an objective way of eliciting brain stem potentials in response to audiological click stimuli. These waves are recorded by electrodes placed over the scalp. This investigation was first described by Jewett and Williston in 1971.

Procedure: The stimulus either in the form of click is transmitted to the ear via a transducer placed in the insert ear phone. The wave forms are generated at the level of brain stem are recorded by the placement of electrodes over the scalp.

The waveforms are numbered by the Roman numerals I - VII. Wave V is the most important and reliable wave.

BERA is the gold standard diagnostic test for hearing loss but Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) is the ideal hearing screening modality.

questions.text: Which  of the following cause referred otalgia through Vagus nerve except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hypopharyngeal malignancy

Great auricular nerve supplies the lower half of pinna on both medial and lateral aspects. Upper half on the lateral aspect is supplied by the Auriculotemporal nerve while the medial aspect is supplied by the Lessser Occipital nerve. Concha of the pinna is supplied by the Auricular branch of Vagus External auditory canal is supplied by the Auriculotemporal nerve anteriorly and the Auricular branch of Vagus posteriorly. ( Arnold’s nerve or Aldermann’s nerve ). Cough reflex on cleaning the ear is mediated through the Auricular branch of Vagus. A small area on the posterosuperior wall of the external auditory meatus is supplied by the sensory root of Facial nerve ( Nerve of wirsberg) ). Jacobson’s nerve is tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve which supplies middle ear. Stapedius muscle is supplied by facial nerve. Tensor tympani is suppled by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve

questions.text: A 50 year old female patient has presented with the complaint of long standing left ear discharge, foul smelling, blood stained. She has left sided facial palsy. She also gives history of ear ache which is worse at night. On otoscopy, friable granulations are seen in the middle ear. What is the most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Malignancy of middle ear

This patient is middle aged with long standing ear discharge and ear ache worse at night.. it is a feature of Malignancy of ear.

.Malignant otitis externa= Skull base osteomyelitis

     locally destructive infection of bony EAC which is part of skull base. The infection spreds to skull base therefore this disease is actually skull base osteomyelitis

     caused by  pseudomonas

     predisposing factors

      • Diabetes
      • Elderly
      • Immunosuppressed

     local destruction can involve skull base, mastoid, petrous apex, etc,

There are granulations is the external auditory canal which leads to blood stained ear discharge. Patient has severe ear ache.

 

     Cranial nerve palsies (7, 9-12) can be there – facial nerve is the most commonly involved nerve

    

Treatment:

    • antibiotics (3rd Generation cephalosporins, high dose ciprofloxacin)
    • debridment if no response to medical treatment
    • management of underlying cause

 

Radionucleide gallium ( good for prognostic evaluation) and technetium scan ( good for diagnosis) are helpful in the management. Also ESR is a good tool to monitor disease activity

questions.text: One of the following is not a common feature of  Vestibular schwannoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Facial Palsy
Acoustic neuromas account for 80% of tumors found within the cerebellopontine angle. The remaining 20% are mainly meningiomas. More than 90% of acoustic neuromas (eighth nerve schwannomas) arise from the vestibular division of the nerve. The superior and inferior vestibular nerves appear to be the nerves of origin with about equal frequency. Recently, a higher predominance has been attributed to inferior vestibular nerve.

Vestibular schwannomas characteristically present as progressive unilateral hearing loss. Hearing loss is present in 95% of patients. Destruction of vestibular fibres is slow. Therefore, many patients do not experience disequilibrium or vertigo. As a vestibular schwannoma grows, it can compress the trigeminal nerve, thereby causing loss of corneal reflex as the first sign.

The definitive diagnostic test for patients with acoustic neuroma is gadolinium-enhanced MRI. 

They are densely and uniformly enhancing neoplasms on MRI. Vestibular schwannomas enlarge the internal auditory canal. This feature helps to distinguish them from other cerebellopontine angle masses.

Treatment is surgical excision. 

 Stereotactic radiotherapy (Gamma Knife)is an alternative to surgery for selected patients who cannot tolerate a surgical procedure with acoustic neuroma. It uses radiation delivered to a precise point.

questions.text: The most common site of cholesteatoma in middle ear is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Prussack’s space

questions.text: Which of the following is  not a canal wall down (CWU) otological procedure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Schwartz Operation

Canal wall down (CWD) procedures

     modified radical mastoidectomy, radical mastoidectomy, atticotomy    

Canal wall up  (CWU) procedures

          cortical mastoidectomy ( schwartz operation), combined approach tympanoplasty

choices.text: Acyclovir should be added to treatment
Continue with steroids and repeat assesment

questions.text:
A patient of bell’s palsy shows no improvement with 3 weeks of steroid therapy. His electroneuronography reveals no significant facial nerve degeneration .

 What should be the next step in the management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Continue with steroids and repeat assesment
Bell’s palsy is idiopathic sudden onset lower motor neuron facial palsy. In lower motor neuron facial palsy, forehead muscles are also involved . (Supranuclear spares the forehead). Herpes simplex is being postulated as an aetiology for Bell’s palsy.Steroids are the main stay of management. A patient who reports within first three days should be given acyclovir as well. Care of the eye is a very important part of management to prevent exposure keratopathy. Chances of recovery in Bell’s palsy are 85% and above.

If there is no recovery after 3 weeks of steroid therapy, electrophysiological nerve testing should be done ( Electroneuronography). If there is significant facial nerve degeneration, patient should be taken for surgery (facial nerve decompression) should be done

questions.text: Which is not found on the medial wall of middle ear
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Facial Recess
See question no. 4 explanation

choices.text: Cell balls of Zellballen on histopathology

questions.text: All are clinically applicable statements to glomus Jugulare except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intralesional Bleomycin is standard therapy

Glomus jugulare is a variety of paraganglinoma which originates from glomus cells lying around the jugular bulb. It is more common in females It’s a benign non capsulated locally invasive tumour. It is a highly vascular tumour of skull base which leads to pulsatie tinnitus.  It erodes the floor of middle ear and start appearing in the middle ear in the hypotympanum as red vascular mass (Rising sun sign). When it enters EAC, there is bleeding from ear canal. Brown sign is on otoscopy when tumour blanches on seigelisation.

remember rule of 10 % for paraganglinomas—10% are multicentric, 10 % are secretory, 10 % are familial

It spreads on skull base which leads to erosion of septum between carotid canal and jugular foramen (Phelp sign). It can cause 7,9 10, 11, 12 cranial nerve palsy.

Biopsy is contraindicated.

Since it is a variety of paraganglionoma ( other eg. Pheochromocytoma)—therefore urinary VMA levels should be done.

Preoperative embolisation helps to reduce blood loss during surgery

questions.text:
A Patient has developed Sudden Sensorineural Hearing loss on Right side.
 
What all can be part of management of this patient except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Caroverine

It’s a case of Sudden SNHL.

 A commonly used criterion to qualify for this diagnosis is a sensorineural hearing loss of greater than 30 dB over 3 contiguous pure-tone frequencies occurring within 3 days' period. Usually it presents as unilateral loss of hearing; bilateral involvement is rare

Causes :

1. Infections : Mumps, herpes zoster, meningitis, encephalitis, syphilis, otitis media

2. Trauma : Head injury, ear operations, noise trauma, barotrauma, spontaneous rupture of cochlear membranes

3. Vascular haemorrhage ( leukemia), embolism or thrombosis of labyrinthine or cochlear artery or their vasospasm. They may be associated with diabetes, hypertension, polycythemia, macroglobinaemia or sickle cell trait

Treatment :

1. Bed rest

2. Steroid therapy

3. Inhalation of carbogen (5% CO2 + 95% O2) increases cochlear blood flow

4. Vasodilator drugs

5. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy

choices.text: The vertigo sensation persists for 2-3 hours
Otoconia most commonly migrate to Posterior semicircular canal to cause this entity
There is no hearing loss in this condition
BPPV is the most common cause of peripheral vertigo

questions.text: All are true about benign paroxysmal positional vertigo except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The vertigo sensation persists for 2-3 hours

BPPV

Otoliths or otoconia are calcium carbonate crystals lying embedded in the gelatinous layer of macula. Macula is the sensory end organ of utricle and saccule whose function is linear acceleration.

 BPPV

  • Displaced otoconia from macula is the aetiology
  • Most commonly otoliths come to lie in posterior semicircular canal
  • Dix hallpike’s test is diagnostic
  • Epley’s maneuver Or Semont’s maneuver is therapeutic which is particle repositioning maneuver

questions.text: Identify the given instrument used in evaluation of Eustachian tube function
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Politzer bag

Tests for eustachian tube patency

Valselva’s manoeuvre ( needs a pressure of 33mm Hg to open the tube) ,

Eustachian tube catheterization

Politzerization using a politzer bag ( shown in picture)

Tympanometry

Sachharine test

questions.text: Identify the prosthesis given in the picture used in treatment of serous otitis media
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Middle ear Ventilation tube

OTITIS MEDIA WITH EFFUSION (O.M.E.) OTITIS MEDIA WITH EFFUSION (O.M.E.)

= glue ear, som (Secretory otitis media)

Definition:

OME :- Is accumulation of non purulent fluid in the middle ear.

•   Incidence highest in School going children due to ET blockage due to adenoid hypertrophy

Feature

- Hearing loss

- Delayed speech development

- heaviness in the ear

Otoscopy :-Tympanic membrane :- dull

- Retraction / ¯ mobility of TM

- Air fluid level behind / bubbles

INVESTIGATIONS

•   Pure tone audiometry : Conductive Hearing loss  (20-40 dB)

•   Impedance audiometry : Type B curve.

TREATMENT . Myringotomy and grommet insertion in the anteroinferior quadrant of tympanic membrane. Also, adenoidectomy is an important part of Treatment

choices.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential is a useful investigation

questions.text: All are characteristic features of superior semicircular canal dehiscence except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Sensorineural hearing loss on audiometry
Superior semicircular canal dehiscence is either traumatic or congenital. Patient complains of vertigo especially on hearing loud sounds (tullio’s phenomenon). Patient shows conductive hearing loss on audiometry due to leakage of sound energy from third window which has been created in SCC (apart from oval and round window). HRCT temporal bone is the diagnostic investigation. Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMP) is also helpful in its diagnosis

questions.text:
A 5 year old patient presents with the history of hearing loss. On examination he is found to have a pearly white mass behind the intact tympanic membrane.

What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Congenital cholesteatoma
Congenital cholesteatomas are believed to arise from embryonal inclusions or rests of epithelial cells.  
Levenson, established a set of criteria for the definition of congenital cholesteatoma in the middle ear.  These criteria included, (1) a white mass medial to a normal tympanic membrane, (2) a normal pars flaccida and pars tensa, (3) no prior otologic procedures. In addition, prior bouts of otitis media were not grounds for exclusion

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is given in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type B Curve

questions.text: A patient of right unsafe CSOM has presented with history of diplopia and pain behind the right eye. What is the further ideal investigation in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
HRCT temporal bone
Petrous apex may be pneumatized in about 30% cases with connecting cell tracts from the mastoid. This may hence predispose to spread of infection to the petrous apex from middle ear suppuration. There is secondary involvement of Vth and VIth cranial nerves which are closely related to the petrous apex.
 Gradenigo’s syndrome 
The triad of otorrhoea, retro orbital pain ( due to Trigeminal neuealgia) and diplopia ( Lateral Rectus palsy due to Abducent nerve involvent ) in apical petrositis is known as Gradenigo’s Syndrome.

choices.text: Atticoantral CSOM with Lateral sinus thrombosis

questions.text: Mohan, 22 year old, male gives history of right sided ear discharge, foul smelling and occasionally blood stained for last 6 years. He also complains of hearing loss for last 2 years. For last 3 days patient has developed fever with chills, headache and pallor and oedema over mastoid region. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Atticoantral CSOM with Lateral sinus thrombosis

questions.text:
A 50 year old male patient presenting with hearing loss complaint on left side was subjected to audiometry. His audiogram is shown below

What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
In this PTA, there is no ac, bc gap which is suggestive of SNHL. AB gap is suggestive of conductive hearing loss.
Dip at 4000 Hz in AC and BC curve in audiogram is suggestive of noise induced hearing loss
Dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve is seen in Otosclerosis ( Carhart’s Notch)

choices.text: Hyperacusis is seen in these cases

questions.text: False regarding Bell’s palsy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Forehead muscles are not paralysed
Bell’s palsy is idiopathic sudden onset lower motor neuron facial palsy. In lower motor neuron facial palsy, forehead muscles are also involved . (Supranuclear spares the forehead). Herpes simplex is being postulated as an aetiology for Bell’s palsy.Steroids are the main stay of management. A patient who reports within first three days should be given acyclovir as well. Care of the eye is a very important part of management to prevent exposure keratopathy. Chances of recovery in Bell’s palsy are 85% and above.

questions.text:
Patient has the complaint of right sided hearing loss and left ear hearing is normal.

 Tuning fork tests show that Rinne is Negative on right side and positive on left side. 

Weber test is lateralised towards left ear. 

Absolute bone conduction (ABC) test is normal on left side but decreased on right side.
What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Right sensorineural hearing loss

Tuning Fork Test

Tuning fork of 512Hz is ideal. Forks of lower frequency produce sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequency have a shorter decay time

To test AC - A vibratory fork is placed vertically about 2cm away from the opening of EAM

AC tests the function of both conducting mechanism & the cochlea. Normally, hearing through air conduction is louder & heard twice as long as through bone conduction route.

To test BC - Footplate of vibratory fork is placed firmly on the mastoid bone. Cochlea is stimulated directly by vibrations conducted through skull bone. BC is a measure of the cochlear function only

1. Rinnie Test : In this AC. of the ear is compared with its BC. It is +ve when AC > BC ( normal / SN deafness ).  If -ve Rinne  BC > AC in conductive deafness

False -ve rinne : Severe unilateral SNHL. This is prevented by masking the non test ear

2. Weber Test : Normally, it is heard equally in both ear

Lateralised to the worse ear in conductive deafness. Lateralised to the better ear in SN deafness

3. Absolute bone conduction (ABC) test : In this patient's bone conduction is compared with that of the examiner. EAM of both patient & examiner should be occluded. In SN deafness , patient hears for a shorter duration

choices.text: Sensory end organ of Utricle and saccule
Sensory end organ of semicircular canals

questions.text: What is Cupula in inner ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Gelatinous layer around Crista
Cupula is the gelatinous layer around Crista( the sensory end organ of Semicircular canals)

choices.text: Transverse fractures are more commonly associated with facial palsy
Ear bleeding is suggestive of longitudinal fractures
CSF otorrhoea is more common in transverse fractures
Longitudinal fractures more commonly cause conductive deafness

questions.text: All of the following are true about temporal bone fractures except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CSF otorrhoea is more common in transverse fractures

longitudinal fracture of temporal bone.

The ear bleeding is a feature of longitudinal fracture. This fracture is due to fall on the side. Battle sign is ecchymosis around the mastoid tip area which is seen in temporal bone fractures. This fracture causes ossicular dislocation and hence conductive hearing loss. Transverse fractures lead to cochlear injury and hence cause SNHL. CSF otorrhoea is more common with longitudinal fractures

 

In temporal bone fractures, the facial palsy is either of immediate (Transverse fractures) or delayed onset  ( Longitudinal fractures)

 

Immediate onset need immediate surgery which is facial nerve decompression and if need be end to end anastomosis or nerve grafting

 

Delayed onset should be managed with 3 weeks of steroid therapy as the cause is oedema in this case. If there is no recovery after 3 weeks of steroid therapy, electrophysiological nerve testing should be done ( Electroneuronography). If there is significant facial nerve degeneration, patient should be taken for surgery (facial nerve decompression) should be done.

questions.text: What is the name of this middle ear prosthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Stapedial piston prosthesis
PORP ( Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis) is used in Type III tympanoplasty situation when malleus and incus are absent

TORP ( Total ossicular replacement prosthesis) is used in Type IV tympanoplasty situation when malleus , incus and stapes head  are absent and only footplate is there.

choices.text: It is obliquely placed at an angle of 55 degrees with horizontal plane.
The posterosuperior part is more medial than anteroinferior part
Peripheral portion is more mobile than the centre of tympanic membrane.
Umbo is the tip of handle of malleus; a landmark on its surface

questions.text: All are true about tympanic membrane except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
The posterosuperior part is more medial than anteroinferior part
TM consists of 3 layers : as it develops from ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm

i) Outer epithelial layer which is continuous with skin in the meatus
ii) Inner mucosal layer which is continuous with mucosa of middle ear
iii) Middle fibrous layer which encloses handle of malleus & has 3 types of  fibers- radial, circular & parabolic

It is positioned at angle of 55° to the floor. This angle is attained at 4-5 yrs age. 
The posterosuperior wall is more lateral than the anteromedial wall
Umbo is the tip of handle of malleus. It is the most reliable landmark on surface of tympanic membrane

choices.text: Mastoid tip develops by 2years of age
Middle ear ossicles attain adult size by 6 years of age

questions.text: All are true about embryology of ear development except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Middle ear ossicles attain adult size by 6 years of age
Pinna develops from first and second arch. EAC develops from first branchial cleft and eustachian tube from first branchial pouch. Tragus develops from first arch, rest of pinna from second arch. Malleus and incus develops from first arch. Stapes from second arch. Cochlea develops from neuroectoderm ( otic capsule). Pinna and cochlea develops by 20th week. 
Middle ear ossicles and cochlea are fully grown at  the time of birth

questions.text: Identify the investigation being done in the given picture
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Vestibular Evoked Myogenic potential
In VEMP, we stimulate the saccule with sound and we record the contractions of Sternocleidomastoid muscle ( Vestibulocollic reflex). This test checks the inferior vestibular division of 8th nerve as saccule is supplied by this nerve.

questions.text:
A patient of head injury suffered hearing loss. He has normal tympanic membrane with  type Ad Tympanogram.

 How much conductive hearing loss is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
54 dB  
Hearing loss in
 Ossicular Dislocation with Intact TM- 54 dB
Ossicular Dislocation with perforated TM- 38 dB
Glue Ear – 10-40 dB
Wax—30 dB

questions.text:
A child is born with deformed pinna. ( see picture)

What is the name of this deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Bat ear
Bat ear is a cosmetic deformity in which antihelix is poorly developed. The plastic reconstruction is done after  6 years of age because pinna grows fully by that time

questions.text: All are true about retrocochlear hearing loss except

Recruitment is present

questions.solution:

Reissner’s membrane
Basilar membrane separates Scala Media and Scala Tympani
Reissner’s membrane separates Scala Vestibuli and Scala media
Tectorial membrane covers Organ of corti

Transmitter

          caused by  pseudomonas

          predisposing factors

      • Diabetes

          local destruction can involve skull base, mastoid, petrous apex, etc,

There are granulations is the external auditory canal which leads to blood stained ear discharge. Patient has severe ear ache.

 

          Cranial nerve palsies (7, 9-12) can be there – facial nerve is the most commonly involved nerve

         

Treatment:

    • antibiotics (3rd Generation cephalosporins, high dose ciprofloxacin)

Radionucleide gallium ( good for prognostic evaluation) and technetium scan ( good for diagnosis) are helpful in the management. Also ESR is a good tool to monitor disease activity

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of auditory brainstem implant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Mondini’s dysplasia of cochlea
Brain stem implant is placed on lateral recess of 4th ventricle near cochlear nucleus for stimulation.

questions.text: The most common site of origin of Acoustic neuroma is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Inferior vestibular division of 8th nerve
Acoustic neuromas account for 80% of tumors found within the cerebellopontine angle. The remaining 20% are mainly meningiomas. More than 90% of acoustic neuromas (eighth nerve schwannomas) arise from the vestibular division of the nerve. The superior and inferior vestibular nerves appear to be the nerves of origin with about equal frequency. Recently, a higher predominance has been attributed to inferior vestibular nerve.

Vestibular schwannomas characteristically present as progressive unilateral hearing loss. Hearing loss is present in 95% of patients. Destruction of vestibular fibres is slow. Therefore, many patients do not experience disequilibrium or vertigo. As a vestibular schwannoma grows, it can compress the trigeminal nerve, thereby causing loss of corneal reflex as the first sign.

questions.text: In a patient of facial nerve injury  -----Schirmer’s test shows decresed lacrimation, taste sensation is impaired and stapedial reflex is absent. Where is the level of injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Labyrinthine segment of facial nerve 
Topodiagnostic Tests 
1. Schirmer's Test - Reduced lacrimation - lesion proximal to geniculate ganglion ( first genu)
2. Stapedial Reflex - Lost in lesions above N. to Stapedius ( above second genu)
3. Taste test - Impairment of taste means lesion above chorda tympnai origin

choices.text: Hearing loss should be more than 30 dB
Hearing loss should be seen on minimum 3 frequencies
Hearing loss should have occurred within 3 days
Bilateral Hearing loss should be there

questions.text: One of the following is not the criteria to label a hearing loss as Sudden SNHL
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Bilateral Hearing loss should be there
A commonly used criterion to qualify for the diagnosis of sudden SNHL is a sensorineural hearing loss of greater than 30 dB over 3 contiguous pure-tone frequencies occurring within 3 days' period. Usually it presents as unilateral loss of hearing; bilateral involvement is rare

choices.text: Medial 24 mm is cartilaginous and lateral 12 mm is bony
Its angled at 45 degrees with horizontal at birth
The opening of Eustachian tube lies 1.25 cm behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate in the nasopharynx
Tensor palati  is the main muscle to open the Eustachian tube

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Its angled at 45 degrees with horizontal at birth
Eustachian tube is otherwise known as pharyngotympanic tube, middle ear ventilation tube. It is bony cartilagenous in nature. It connects the middle ear with the nasopharynx. In adults it lies at an angle of 45 degrees to the horizontal plane. In infants this inclination is about 10 degrees. In adults its length is 38mm. For descriptive purposes it can be divided into posterior 1/3 which is osseus in nature and anterior 2/3 which is cartilagenous in nature. This tube passes through sinus of Morgagni to enter the nasopharynx and opens 1.25 cm behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate.
Usually the eustachean tube is closed; it opens during such actions like swallowing, yawning thus equalising the middle ear pressure. Active dilatation of the tube is induced by the tensor palati muscle. Closure of the tube has been attributed to passive reapproximation of tubal walls by extrinsic forces exerted by surrounding elastic fibres.

questions.text: High frequency audiometry is used in –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Ototoxicity
Ototoxic drugs--
1.	Aminoglycosides	: 
A. Vestibulotoxic drugs: damage hair cells of crista
Streptomycin , gentamicin, tobramycin 
B. Cochleotoxic drugs: damage outer hair cells of cochlea (starting from basal turn to apex)- high frequency loss 	Neomycin, kanamycin, amikacin
									
2.	Loop diuretics:  cause oedema of stria vascularis
	furosemide, ethacrynic acid

3.	Analgesics:  salicylates ( aspirin)- indomethacin Ibuprofen

	4. Antimalarials --quinine-chloroquine
	
	5. Anticancer drugs : cisplatin carboplatin, Vincristine

	6.Chelating agent: desferoxamine

 	 7. Antibiotics:Vancomycin, erythromycin
Ototoxicity involves high frequencies more than the low frequencies. Therefore high frequency audiometry is useful in its diagnosis

choices.text: Protective reflex for middle ear function

questions.text: True about stapedial reflex is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Absent in cases of otosclerosis
Stapedial reflex is protective reflex for inner ear. Its afferent is 8th nerve and efferent is 7th nerve. It is absent in deafness, facial nerve lesions and Otosclerosis

choices.text: Abnormal collection of cerumen in the outer part of external auditory canal
Abnormal collection of cerumen in the deeper part of external auditory canal
Abnormal epithelial migration of skin of external auditory canal
Chronic foul smelling ear discharge present in external auditory canal

questions.text: Keratosis obturans is caused due to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Abnormal epithelial migration of skin of external auditory canal

Keratosis obturans: is accumulation of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. Keratosis obturans is postulated to occur due to abnormal epithelial migration of ear canal skin. The movement of the surface epithelium appears to be reversed in these patients. The ear canal appears to be widened. CT scan of temporal bones may reveal canal erosion and widening. There may be ersoin of facial canal in some cases.

Management:

1. Surgical removal under G.A.
2. Canal plasty is helpful in recurrent cases

questions.text: Wet Newspaper’ like appearance in external auditory canal is a feature of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Otomycosis
This kind of appearance is seen in otomycosis. This is the appearance of fungal mass in the EAC which appears as wet piece of paper

choices.text: A Vertical bony septum in Internal Auditory meatus
A horizontal crest on medial wall of middle ear

questions.text: What is Bill’s bar?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A Vertical bony septum in Internal Auditory meatus

Bill's bar is a landmark that divides the superior compartment of the internal acoustic meatus into an anterior and posterior compartment. Anterior to Bill bar, in the anterior superior quadrant, are the facial nerve (CN VII) and nervus intermedius, and posterior to it in the posterior superior quadrant is the superior division of the vestibular nerve

questions.text: Which is not a clinical feature of Herpes Zoster Oticus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Universal recovery of facial function
Ramsay Hunt syndrome= Herpes zoster oticus
	* Facial paralysis (Lower motor neuron)	
* Vesicular rash in EAC & Pinna	
* Anaesthesia of face, giddiness & hearing impairment due to involvement of 5th & 8th N.
T/t : Acyclovir, steroids

questions.text:
CT scan of neck of a patient of carcinoma larynx has been found to have the involvement of epiglottis, left aryepiglottic fold, left arytenoid, left vocal cord with the invasion of Thyroid cartilage.
What is the ideal treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Total laryngectomy + radiotherapy
This is the stage T4 of cancer larynx as there is involvement of Thyroid cartilage. Therefore total laryngectomy and radiotherapy is required in this case.
The treatment of choice for T3 and T4 cancer larynx is total laryngectomy followed by RT. However, certain cancer study groups recommend the use of concurrent chemoradiation with Cisplatin for T3 cancer larynx as an alternative to total laryngectomy. Though, the 5 year survival rate with concurrent chemoradiation is lower as compared to surgical management.

questions.text:
A 42 year old patient singer by profession has developed choked voice. On fiberoptic stroboscoy of larynx, he is found to have hyperadduction of true vocal cords while phonating.
What is the name of this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Adductor Spasmodic dysphonia
Dysphonia Plica Ventricularis is the production of sound from false vocal cords.
Mogiophonia is speech defect in public appearance only
Rhinolalia clausa is hyponasality. This is due to nasal obstruction, nasal polyp, sinusitis, adenoid hypertrophy, angiofibroma.
Rhinolalia aperta is hypernasality. This is due to cleft palate,palatal perforation,palatal palsy
In adductor spasmodic dysphonia, patient has choked voive ( strangulated voice)
In abductor SD, the voice is breathy.

choices.text: Involvement of posterior part of larynx

questions.text: All of the following are true for Lupus of larynx except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Painless disease
Lupus larynx involves the anterior part of larynx – epiglottis is the commonest site . Lupus of larynx is painless condition
Tuberculosis of larynx is a painful condition.. Tuberculosis of larynx mostly involves posterior part of larynx. Its first sign is hyperemia of vocal cords. Its first sign is weakness of voice. The other signs are turban epiglottis and mouse bitten appearance of vocal cords.

questions.text:
A 20 year old male patient has high pitch voice. His fiberoptic laryngoscopy is normal. The clinician has advised him for speech therapy in which he is asked to phonate while pulling the thyroid cartilage downwards and pressing it backwards.
What is the name of this manoeuvre?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gutzmann’s manoeuvre

Gutzmann’s manoeuvre is used in the management of Puberphonia. If patient is not relieved with speech therapy, then Type III thyroplasty is done.

questions.text: All of the following can not be seen on indirect laryngoscopy except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Interarytenoid area
Structures which cannot be seen on indirect laryngoscopy are..
a. Laryngeal surface of epiglottis
b. anterior commissure of vocal cords
c. ventricle
d. subglottis

questions.text:
A patient of T3NoMo carcinoma larynx has undergone total laryngectomy. He has permanent tracheostomy following this surgery. HE is using the device given in picture for vocal rehabilitation.

What is the name of this device?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Electrolarynx device

Electrolarynx or artificial larynx is a hand held device.

Blom singer prosthesis is a tracheoesophageal puncture device. It is a one way valve surgically placed between trachea and esophagus. It is used for vocal rehabilitation after laryngectomy. It  sends air from trachea to esophagus which is used to produce voice. But it does not let the food particles to go from esophagus to trachea so aspiration is not significant

questions.text:
A 33 year old female patient has suddenly developed Aphonia. Her Laryngeal endoscopy picture shows immobile cords as shown in the picture.

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Bilateral adductor palsy
Both the vocal cords are lying immobile in intermediate or cadaveric position. There is no adduction .
So the diagnosis is bilateral adductor palsy

choices.text: Early vocal cord nodules are managed with speech therapy
Pachydermia laryngis is a premalignant condition
Reinke’s oedema is best managed with decortication of vocal cords
Co2  laser is very useful in management of  juvenile papilloma  of  larynx

questions.text: Vocal cord lesions: all are true except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Pachydermia laryngis is a premalignant condition
Pachydermia laryngis is not a premalignant condition. It is heaping up of epithelium in the interarytenoid region due to vocal abuse and laryngopharyngeal reflux.

choices.text: Respiratory distress with poor quality of voice

questions.text: A 52 year old female patient underwent total thyroidectomy. While surgery, both side superior laryngeal nerves got damaged. What are the expected post operative symptoms of patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Poor quality of voice & aspiration
SLN supplies cricothyroid and sensory supply to Supraglottis part of larynx. Cricothyroid is tensor muscle which gives quality to voice. So patient have loss of quality of voice and Aspiration

questions.text:
A 3 month old child has persistent dyspnoea and stridor since birth. The cry of the baby is normal. On CT scan of neck, the subglottic diameter has been found to be 2.5 mm.

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Congenital subglottic stenosis

Montgomery’s silicon T tube is used for laryngotracheal reconstruction. This tube is used to support the reconstructed segment for 6 weeks

choices.text: Usual site of tracheostomy is 2nd and 3rd tracheal ring
In children, a circular ring of anterior tracheal wall is removed
An elective tracheostomy is done with horizontal incision.

questions.text: All are true about tracheostomy except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
In children, a circular ring of anterior tracheal wall is removed 
High trachestomy means when it starts from first ring. It is only done in a case of cancer larynx. Otherwise, the level of tracheostomy is 2nd and 3rd rings. If we involve first ring, it can cause subglottic stenosis later on. In pediatric trachestomy, we don’t remove circular ring of anterior tracheal wall because this can lead to tracheomalacia later on. In adults we do remove a circular ring of anterior tracheal wall to place the tube. 
High volume and low pressure cuff of tracheostomy tube is better as this will prevent tracheomalacia

choices.text: Identifying the mobility of vocal cord
Identification of preservation of normal mucosal wave of vocal cord
Malignant lesions are seen in blue color

questions.text: Stroboscopy of larynx helps to differentiate benign from early malignant lesions of vocal cord by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 Identification of preservation of normal mucosal wave of vocal cord
Stroboscopy: This is an excellent tool for examining the movements of the vocal cords  in their various phases.Stroboscopic images are generated  using a flashing light source create the illusion of slow motion Strobolaryngoscopy takes advantage of these principles by producing intermittent light flashes in close relation to the frequency of the vocal-fold vibration. A microphone picks up the frequency of the examinee's sustained voice, which triggers the stroboscopic light source. With the provision that the vocal vibrations are periodic, a frequency of light flashes equal to the vocal frequency produces a clear, still image of the same portion to the vibratory cycle

questions.text: An infant after birth is noticed to have stridor and a hoarse cry. All of the following diagnosis are possible except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Laryngomalacia

Laryngomalacia =congenital laryngeal stridor

  • Most common congenital anamoly of larynx
  • Excessive flaccidity of supraglottic larynx , AE folds are weak
  • Inspiratory  stridor increases on crying relieved in prone position
  • Cry is normal
  • Fibreoptic laryngoscopy --  Omega shaped epiglottis
  • No treatment required. It usually disappears by 2 yrs of age

questions.text: Kashima Operation is done for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bilateral abductor palsy

bilateral abductor palsy

. The immediate treatment will be emergency tracheostomy. Then we wait for 6 months, if patient shows no recovery, then the treatment of choice is vocal cord lateralization (type 2 thyroplasty). It is also called suture cordopexy of the vocal cord

Kashima operation is also useful. In this surgery, CO2 laser is used to separate the membranous and cartilaginous part of the vocal cords so that there is some space created for the airway.

Woodman’s operation is arytenoidectomy by open approach. This can also be done

Type 1 thyroplasty is done in the case of bilateral adductor palsy

choices.text: Repeat direct laryngoscopy every hour to assess laryngeal oedema

questions.text: In a patient of acute epiglottitis, all of the following are part of management except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Repeat direct laryngoscopy every hour to assess laryngeal oedema
In Acute Epiglottitis, the airway establishment by intubation or tracheostomy is the first treatment to be given. But repeated direct laryngoscopy should be avoided as this can aggravate the edema of larynx

choices.text: CO2 Laser is helpful in its management
Indole-3-carbinol  derived from cruciferous vegetables has shown some benefit

questions.text: Not True about  Recurrent Respiratory Papillamatosis of Larynx is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Only involve supraglottis and Glottis
Juvenile papillomas are caused by HPV-6,11. The infection is transmitted from mother at the time of birth.They can spread downwards to trachea bronchi lungs.
 CO2 laser is the treatment of choice. Recurrences are common after surgery. are premalignant
Interferon alpha and intralesional cidovofir is helpful in management.
In case of respiratory distress in a patient of juvenile papilloma, tracheostomy should be done. Intubation will lead to spread of disease to trachea, bronchi

choices.text: Argon and KTP laser are visible lasers where as CO2 laser and Nd YAG lasers are invisible
Silicon Endotracheal tube wrapped with metallic foil should be used for laser assisted  laryngeal surgeries
CO2 laser can pass through the flexible endoscopes

questions.text: All of the following are true about lasers in ENT except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
CO2 laser can pass through the flexible endoscopes
CO2 laser can not pass through flexible endoscopes. NdYAG laser can pass through flexible scopes. Carbon dioxide laser is the best laser used for laryngeal procedures. This is the invisible laser and an aiming beam is used to target this laser on to the tissues .  ( 10,600nm wavelength).

choices.text: Sensory supply of infraglottic larynx is by internal laryngeal nerve
Interarytenoid muscle is supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve from both sides

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the anatomy of larynx
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Sensory supply of infraglottic larynx is by internal laryngeal nerve
The sensory supply of larynx till vocal cords is by internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve. Below the vocal cords, the sensory supply is by recurrent laryngeal nerve

choices.text: Stridor with respiratory difficulty is the chief complaint
Atrophy of laryngeal mucosa and crust formation is seen

questions.text: All are true about atrophic laryngitis  except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stridor with respiratory difficulty is the chief complaint

Atrophic laryngitis (laryngitis sicca)

  • Atrophy of laryngeal mucosa & crust formation
  • Often seen in women, a laryngeal counterpart of atrophic rhinitis
  • Associated with atrophic rhinitis and pharyngitis
  • Presents with  dry cough

questions.text: Gold standard test for laryngopharyngeal reflux is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

24 hour double probe pH monitoring

Laryngopharyngeal reflux is best diagnosed with 24 hour double probe pH monitoring.

 

Reflux of acid in throat can cause-

 

  • Pachydermia Larynx ( its not premalignant)
  • Pseudosulcus vocalis
  • Vocal Nodule
  • Vocal Polyp
  • Contact Ulcer of larynx
  • Subglottic stenosis
  • Cancer larynx
  • Unexplained throat pain and dry cough

Laryngeal pseudosulcus is seen in laryngopharyngeal reflux. This sulcus is not attached to the underlying tissues whereas a true vocal cord sulcus is adherent to underlying tissues of vocal cord.

questions.text: The radiological presence of which paranasal sinus appears last in human life
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Frontal sinus

Maxillary sinus -- Present at birth and radiologicaly visualized by 4-5 months of age

- Frontal sinus develops in the fourth year of life.  It is radiograhpically visible in children more than 6 year of age

Ethmoid sinus is present at birth. Radiologically apprecialble by 1 year of age.

Sphenoid sinus is radiologically appreciable by 4 years of age

choices.text: Can be seen in Immunocompetent patients

questions.text: All are true about the entity shown in the CT scan except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Antifungal therapy is primary treatment
Allergic fungal sinusitis is the most common type of fungal sinusitis. The most common organism is Aspergillus fumigates. It is type 1 and 3 allergic reaction to fungal antigens. It has allergic mucin in the nose with nasal polyp formation. These polypi appear heterogenous on CT scan because of fungal colonies into them. The treatment of choice is FESS and steroids. The antifungals are only indicated in invasive variety of fungal sinusitis

questions.text: A wide roomy nasal cavity with thick crust formation and bad odour from nose is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Atrophic Rhinitis

This case is of Atrophic Rhinitis.

The surgical management of atrophic rhinitis includes ---

 

A.Young's operation:- -        Complete Closure of one nostril

B. Modified Young's operation:- - partial closure of both nostrils leaving behind a 3m hole

C. Lautenslager's operation:- Surgical procedures aimed at medializing the lateral nasal wall by injecting Substance like Paraffin , teflon, polythene , cartilage

 

 Rhinoscleroma:

Definition: Chronic, progressive granulomatous infection of nose and upper lip area. This can also involve  larynx ( scleroma Larynx)

Organism: Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Gram negative: Frisch Bacillus).

It is more common in northern part of India

Clinical Picture:

1.Atrophic Stage

Atrophic changes occur in the floor of the nose, septum and turbinates

2. Granulomatous Stage:

 Subdermal infiltration of the lower part of the external nose and the upper lip (woody feel)

3. Cicatrical Stage:    in this stage due to fibrosis, patient develops cosmetic deformity

Diagnosis:                                                                                               

Submucosal infiltration of plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells & Russel bodies                   

Mikulicz Cells:                                                                                                  

Large foam cells with a central nucleus & vacuolated cytoplasm (contain the bacilli)

Russell Bodies:

Eccentric nucleus and a pink- staining cytoplasm- Look like plasma cells.

Treatment:

1. Streptomycin (2 gm/day)

2. Tetracyline (2 gm/day)

questions.text: A patient of suspected sinusitis has undergone CT scan of sinuses. The radiologist reports an anatomical variation of posterior ethmoid air cell lying in close proximity to optic nerve. Identify the cell.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Onodi cell	
There are variations of ethmoidal air cells. Haller cell is a variation of anterior ethmoid air cells and they lie in relation to orbital floor. Onodi cell is a variation of posterior ethmoid and lie in relation to optic nerve. When present they can increase the chance of complications during FESS

choices.text: Iatrogenic trauma is the commonest cause now a days
Immediate transnasal endoscopic surgical closure of leak site should be done
HRCT skull base is the radiological investigation of choice to detect site of leak
Beta 2 transferrin is helpful in confirmation of diagnosis

questions.text: All of the following are true about CSF rhinorrhoea except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Immediate transnasal endoscopic surgical closure of leak site should be done
CSF rhinorrhea is most commonly from cribriform plate. Beta-2 transferrin is the best confirmatory test. It should be managed initially conservatively with bed rest and antibiotics. If it does not resolve, surgical repair is planned

choices.text: The inspiratory and expiratory air currents pass through middle part of nasal cavity
Sinuses are mainly ventilated during inspiratory phase of respiration
Nasal cilia beat 10-20 times per second and mucociliary clearance time is 10 -20 minutes
Nasal cycle of rhythmic congestion and decongestion varies every 2.5 to 4 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about physiology of nose
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Sinuses are mainly ventilated during inspiratory phase of respiration
The sinuses are ventilated during expiratory phase of respiration. Please remember the rest three points in the question

questions.text: A 37 year old patient with Diabetic Ketoacidosis is admitted in ICU. On ENT examination, he is found to be having blackish mass in the nose and necrosis of skin of external nose. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mucormycosis

Mucormycosis (rhinocerebral phycomycosis):

1. Is an aggressive opportunistic fungal infection

2. Organism: Order: Mucor/Rhizopus oryzae

3.  Predisposing factors: immunosuppressed patients, uncontrolled young diabetics

 

Features:

1. Remarkable affinity for blood vessels- arteries

2. Leads to extensive endothelial damage & thrombosis

 

Findings:

The disease begins in the nose, invade à P.N.S à orbit à cribiform plateà meninges àbrain

 

Typical Finding

1. Black necrotic mass seen filling the entire nasal cavity

2. Erosion of the nasal septrum and the hard palate may be appreciable

There is anesthesia over face, nose with reduced mucosal bleeding

 

M.R.I. Detects early vascular and intracranial invasion

 

Treatment:

  • Systemic amphotericin ( Liposomal)
  • Local drainage and debridement

choices.text: Arises  from Upper part of nasal septum

questions.text: All statements are true about Ringertz tumour of Nose except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Arises from Upper part of nasal septum

Ringertz tumour is other name of inverted papilloma of nose. It is a benign but locally invasive tumour and can show malignant conversion. It arises from lateral wall of nose . Its more common in males in 40-70 years of age. Medial maxillectomy will be ideal treatment for this locally invasive tumour as this will remove its site of origin.


Ohngren’s line is from medial canthus of the eye to the angle of mandible. This line divides maxilla into superstructure and infrastructure. The malignancy of superstructure has poor prognosis due to proximity to orbit.

In woodworker’s the adenocarcinomas are more common and that too of ethmoid sinus. In total maxillary sinus is the most common sinus to develop malignancy. In nickel exposed patents, the most common malignancy is squamous cell carcinoma

choices.text: Osteomas are most commonly seen in frontal sinus
Malignancy is most common in Maxillary sinus
Fungal balls are most common in Ethmoid sinus
Mucoceles are most common in Frontal sinus

questions.text: Which is not a true statement
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Fungal balls are most common in Ethmoid sinus
Fungal balls or aspergilloma are most commonly seen in maxillary sinus. Mucocecles are most common in frontal sinus. Osteomas are most common in frontal sinus. Malignancy is most common in maxillary sinus.
Ethmoid bone is a single bone which lies between two orbits. Therefore, ethmoid sinusitis is most likely to cause orbital infection

choices.text: Endoscopic removal is the preferred treatment

questions.text: Which statement is true about Ethmoidal  polyp
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Recurrences are common after surgery
Recurrences are more common in Ethmoidal polypi after removal as they are allergic in origin. AC polyp is more common in children and its better seen on posterior rhinoscopy.
FESS is the treatment of choice for AC polyp. For recurrent AC polyp ( second recurrence), Caldwell Luc’s operation is done.

questions.text: Which structure cannot be approached through transnasal endoscopic surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Lacrimal gland 
Think about anatomy… lacrimal glands lie in lateral part of orbit. Lacrimal sac can be approached through transnasal route and hence we do endoscopic DCR these days for epiphora . 
Also, the most common approach for pituitary adenomas these days is transnasal transspehnoid approach

choices.text: Foley’s catheter placement in the nose and inflate the bulb

questions.text: A 62 year old man comes to emergency at 4.00 am with severe epistaxis and high blood pressure (180/110mm Hg). Management of hypertension started. But the epistaxis could not be controlled on anterior nasal packing and posterior nasal packing. What is the next best management of this patient--
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Endoscopic ligation of Sphenopalatine artery
The blood supply of nose. 80 % is from external carotid artery(ECA) and 20 % is from Internal carotid artery (ICA) via anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries.

Sphenopalatine artery is the most common source of epistaxis in hypertensive patients. 

Rendu Osler Weber disease, also called as hereditary hemorrhagic telengectesia presents with recurrent epistaxis. Septodermoplasty means removal of nasal mucosa and grafting with skin to treat recurrent epistaxis in this condition

questions.text:
A 43 year old patient has been suffering from Acute Frontal Sinusitis. He has developed a painful tender red swelling on the forehead ( see the picture).

What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Pott’s puffy Tumour
Pott’s puffy tumour is osteomyelitis of frontal bone . This happens as a complication of frontal sinusitis. This is more common in adults .The maxillary osteomyelitis is more common in children.

Mulberry like nasal polyp is a feature of Rhinosporidiosis
Mulberry like appearance of nasal mucosa is seen in Inferior turbinate hypertrophy
Strawberry appearance of nasal mucosa is seen in Sarcoidosis
Strawberry gingiva means granular appearance of gums and it is seen in wegner’s granulomatosis

choices.text: Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1 to 8.
Anterior and posterior ethmoid air cells are separated by basal lamella
Bulla ethmoidalis is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell
Haller are posterior ethmoidal air cell lying close to orbital floor

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ethmoid air cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bulla ethmoidalis is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell

  • Agger nasi is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell. It is also called fourth turbinate.
  • Supreme turbinate is a variation. It is another small turbinate sometimes present above superior turbinate.
  • Concha bullosa means pneumatised middle turbinate.
  • Anterior ethmoid air cells are from 2-8.Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1-8
  • Haller cell are anterior ethmoid air cells lying in floor of orbit

questions.text: 16 years old promila presents with pain over the cheek and lower part of orbit. Patient also complains of nasal discharge. Examination Reveals oedema of lower eyelids and purulent discharge in middle meatus. Involvement of which of the following para-nasal sinus is suspected.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Ethmoid  Sinus
Ethmoid bone is a single bone which lies between two orbits. Therefore, ethmoid sinusitis is most likely to cause orbital infection

questions.text:
A 7 year old child while playing fell down. He has developed nasal blockage on both sides and there is swelling around the nose.
What is the further treatment of this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Aspiration of septal swelling
Septal hematoma is generally secondary to traumatic septal hematoma
Septal hematoma is collection of blood between the perichondrium of nasal septum and the septal cartilage.  Nose is the most prominent part of the face and hence is more prone for injuries resulting in a hematoma formation in the nasal septum. It is generally bilateral.       The dominant symptom is nasal obstruction.  The treatment of choice is immediate aspiration or drainage

questions.text: Identify the Finding shown in NCCT of Nose and Paranasal Sinuses ( marked with arrow)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Concha Bullosa

  • Agger nasi is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell.
  • Supreme turbinate is a variation. It is another small turbinate sometimes present above superior turbinate.
  • Concha bullosa means pneumatised middle turbinate.
  • Anterior ethmoid air cells are from 2-8.Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1-8
  • Haller cell are anterior ethmoid air cells lying in floor of orbit
  • Anterior and posterior ethmoid air cells are separated by basal lamella

choices.text: Weber Fergusson incision is used for total maxillectomy
Nickel exposure leads to squamous cell carcinoma of sinuses
Squamous cell carcinomas of sinuses are more common in Furniture industry workers
Tumours of Infrastructure of maxilla carry poor 5 year survival rate

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about malignancy of sinuses except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Squamous cell carcinomas of sinuses are more common in Furniture industry workers
Ohngren’s line is from medial canthus of the eye to the angle of mandible. This line divides maxilla into superstructure and infrastructure. The malignancy of superstructure has poor prognosis due to proximity to orbit.
In woodworker’s the adenocarcinomas are more common and that too of ethmoid sinus. In total maxillary sinus is the most common sinus to develop malignancy. In nickel exposed patents, the most common malignancy is squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: All of the following lead to perforation of Cartilaginous part of nasal septum except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Syphilis
Syphilis causes perforation of bony part of septum. Wegner’s granulomatosis causes perforation of both bony and cartilaginous parts

choices.text: Discontinue oxymetazoline and start steroid nasal spray

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with complaints of chronic nasal congestion. About 2 months earlier, he had an upper respiratory tract infection with rhinorrhea and nasal congestion. Since then he continues to have severe nasal congestion  for which he uses oxymetazoline nasal twice daily. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness to percussion over his maxilla bilaterally. The nares are erythematous, with swollen  turbinates and no purulent discharge. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Discontinue oxymetazoline and start steroid nasal spray

This is  a case of Rhinitis medicamentosa due to overuse of topical decongestant drugs.        

  • T/t: Withdrawal of drugs, and Intranasal nasal steroid spray & Turbinectomy (Some cases if required)

questions.text:
A 2 year old child presents to emergency with fever and respiratory distress. He has drooling of saliva and her mother told he has been refusing feeds since yesterday. Xray soft tissue neck lateral view is shown in picture.

What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute Retropharyngeal abscess

Retropharyngeal Space - Between the buccopharyngeal fascia covering the pharyngeal constrictor  & the prevertebral fascia

          * Extends from base of skull to bifurcation of trachea

          * Divided by a fibrous raphe into 2 (spaces of Gilette)

          * Abscess causes U/L bulge on post pharyngeal wall

Acute retropharyngeal abscess - Commonly seen in children < 3yrs

          * Results of suppuration of retropharyngeal LN

          * In adults - from penetrating injury of post. pharyngeal wall

C/F :  * Dysphagia & difficulty in breathing (prominent symp)

          * Stridor & croupy cough

          * Torticollis

          * Bulge in post. Pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline)

          Xray STN lat. view - widening of prevertebral shadow

T/t - I & D without GA, antibiotics

questions.text: All of the following are part of Laryngopharynx except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Vallecula
Anterior pillar , posterior pillar, palatine tonsil, posterior one third tongue, Vallecula lingual tonsil, soft palate, uvula are parts of oropharynx

choices.text: Physiological enlargement continues upto 6 years of age
Adenoidectomy is contraindicated in submucous cleft palate
Digital palpation of adenoid tissue should be avoided before removal in adenoidectomy

questions.text: Not a true statement regarding adenoids
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Digital palpation of adenoid tissue should be avoided before removal in adenoidectomy

Adenoids: (Nasopharyngeal Tonsil)

Definition; Adenoids are lymphoid tissue located at the junction of nasopharyngeal roof and the posterior pharyngeal wall

Features:

1. Are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium

2. Have no capsule/crypts

3. Are present at birth not visible on X-ray in children under I month of age

4. Clinically seen by the 4th month

5. Visible radiographically in children more than 6 month of age

6. physiologically grow upto 6 years of age

7. Involution after puberty

Before adenoidectomy, the adenoid mass should be palpated before surgery to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out any abnormal vessel overlying the adenoid mass

 

Adenoidectomy is contraindicated in hemorrhagic disorders, cleft palate, bifid uvula, hypernasality

choices.text: Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism

questions.text: All are true about Ludwig’s angina except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism
Ludwig’s angina is infection of floor of mouth= submandibular space caused due to dental infections. The bacteriology is mixed- streptococci and anaerobes. Patient has chin swelling, trismus and occasionally respiratory distress. The treatment is by incision and drainage externally deeper to mylohyoid muscle. Occasionaly, tracheostomy may be needed

questions.text: All of the following are true about Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Sensorineural Hearing loss
All the cranial nerves can be involved in Nasopharyngeal Ca. except 1st, 7th and 8th nerve. 
 Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for all stages of nasopharyngeal carcinoma

questions.text: The investigation of choice for a 12- year- old male child presenting with polypoidal mass in the nose, which bleeds on touch is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
CECT scan + Angiography
Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. 
It’s a highly vascular tumour. CECT scan shows Hollman Miller ( =Antral) sign. Angiography is also done before surgery to identify the main blood supply source of tumour.  Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss.

questions.text: Laser Palatoplasty surgery is done for the management of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Snoring 
Laser Palatoplasty surgery is done for the management of snoring.
Laser Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty surgery is done for the management of obstructive sleep apnoea

questions.text:
A 6 year old  Child was operated for Adeno-tonsillectomy under general anaesthesia. In the evening, patient develops neck spasm and is excessively crying. 

MRI Neck shows Atlantoaxial subluxation.

What is the possible diagnosis in this case--
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Grisel Syndrome
Grisel’s syndrome, defined as subluxation of the atlanto-axial joint, not associated with trauma or bone disease, is found primarily in children. This syndrome has been observed after otolaryngologic procedures such as adenoidectomy. It presents with torticollis, neck stiffness. X-rays and computed tomography scans of the cervical spine can confirm the diagnosis. Early management, consisting of cervical immobilization and medical treatment, is considered the key factor for a satisfactory outcome. Neurological complications have been reported in the literature, ranging from mild paresthesia, clonus, to quadriplegia or acute respiratory failure and death so neurosurgical consultation is required. This complication is more common in Down’s syndrome children.

choices.text: Weber Fergusson’s transmaxillary  approach is ideal for angiofibroma limited to nose & nasopharynx
Superior margin of sphenopalatine foramen is the most common site of origin

questions.text: All of the following are true about juvenile angiofibroma except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Weber Fergusson’s transmaxillary  approach is ideal for angiofibroma limited to nose & nasopharynx
Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. It’s a highly vascular tumour. CECT scan shows Hollman Miller ( =Antral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide ( androgen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss. Debulking or biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.

 Tumours confined to nasopharynx can be approached through Wilson’s transpalatal approach. But tumours extending to cheek would need trans- maxillary approach using weber fergusson incision.

choices.text: Superior constrictor and styloglossus make the bed of tonsil
Internal carotid artery lie one inch lateral to tonsillar bed
Commonest source of bleeding during tonsillectomy is paratonsillar vein ( descending palatine vein)
In tonsillectomy, primary haemorrhage is within first 24 hours and should be re-explored immediately

questions.text: All of the following are true statements regarding tonsil except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In tonsillectomy, primary haemorrhage is within first 24 hours and should be re-explored immediately

(i) Reactionary hemorrhage is seen after 24 hours of tonsillectomy. It is due to slippage of ligature and it should be immediately re-explored under GA.

(ii) Secondary hemorrhage is seen after 5th day of tonsillectomy. It is due to infection of tonsillar fossa and is managed with I/V antibiotics.
